thread.title: Legos are the building blocks of an art controversy
thread.title_full: Legos are the building blocks of an art controversy - Houston Chronicle

author: chron.com
title: Legos are the building blocks of an art controversy
text:
Photo: TOBIAS SCHWARZ, AFP / Getty Images Image 1 of / 5 Caption
Close
Image 1 of 5 Chinese artist Ai Weiwei is pictured prior to a press conference at the University of Fine Arts in Berlin on October 26, 2015. Ai Weiwei, in Germany since July 30, 2015 after being barred from overseas travel for four years, will start as a lecturer at the Berlin University of Fine Arts in November 2015 Chinese artist Ai Weiwei is pictured prior to a press conference at the University of Fine Arts in Berlin on October 26, 2015. Ai Weiwei, in Germany since July 30, 2015 after being barred from overseas travel ... more Image 2 of 5 Chinese artist Ai Weiwei arrives for a news conference about his Einstein Professorship at the University Of Arts (UDK) in Berlin, Monday, Oct. 26, 2015. Ai Weiwei will be starting teaching at the University in the winter semester of 2015-16. Chinese artist Ai Weiwei arrives for a news conference about his Einstein Professorship at the University Of Arts (UDK) in Berlin, Monday, Oct. 26, 2015. Ai Weiwei will be starting teaching at the University ... more Image 3 of 5 Samantha Gaines enjoyed playing among Ai WeiWei's sculptures"Circle of Animals / Zodiac Heads" installation at Hermann Park in 2012. Samantha Gaines enjoyed playing among Ai WeiWei's sculptures"Circle of Animals / Zodiac Heads" installation at Hermann Park in 2012. Photo: Brett Coomer Image 4 of 5 In 2012 Ai's "Circle of Animals / Zodiac Heads" drew attention at Hermann Park. In 2012 Ai's "Circle of Animals / Zodiac Heads" drew attention at Hermann Park. Photo: Molly Glentzer Image 5 of 5 Twelve "Circle of Animals / Zodiac Heads" cast in bronze by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei were shown temporarily in Hermann Park in 2012. Twelve "Circle of Animals / Zodiac Heads" cast in bronze by Chinese artist Ai Weiwei were shown temporarily in Hermann Park in 2012. Photo: Thomas B. Shea Legos are the building blocks of an art controversy 1 / 5 Back to Gallery Legos are suddenly political footballs for one of the world's most famous artists.
Supporters of the legendary dissident Chinese artist Ai Weiwei have quickly organized a campaign to send him loads of Legos after the Danish company that makes the building block toys refused his bulk order.
The company has said it does not want its toys to be used for political purposes, Ai reported on Instagram. He had ordered millions of blocks to create an installation for the National Gallery of Victoria in Melbourne, Australia.
"I was quite surprised when I found out," Ai told New York Times Sinosphere blogger Amy Qin. "A company that sells pens cannot tell a writer that he or she can't do political writing or romantic writing. It's really none of their business."
Now he has a new problem: How to handle incoming Legos from people all over the world who are responding via the hashtag #legosforweiwei.
Houstonians may remember Ai's "Circle of Animals," an installation of monumental bronzes representing the signs of the zodiac that was displayed a few years ago at Hermann Park.
Meanwhile, at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, another famous artist's Lego project is getting less serious play. Olafur Eliasson's "the collectivity project" contains more than 580,000 white Lego bricks. Museum visitors are invited to build an imaginary cityscape with them. Perhaps they'll be inspired to form something slightly different now?
"The collectivity project" is on view in the lobby of the Caroline Wiess Law Building, 1001 Bissonnet, until Jan. 31. Museum admission is $7.50-$15; free on Thursdays.
